articles.headline: Citizen Vigilance Leads to Toy Recalls
articles.snippet: Flawed products including poisonous toothpaste, baby bibs containing lead and children’s bracelets with cadmium have been discovered and reported by individuals this year.
articles.abstract: Flawed products including poisonous toothpaste, baby bibs containing lead and children’s bracelets with cadmium have been discovered and reported by individuals this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Consumer Product Safety Commission ordered a recall of half a million pieces of lead jewelry yesterday, it had two unusual partners: Ward Stone and his 10-year-old daughter, Montana.

articles.headline: Foreign Fighters in Iraq Are Tied to Allies of U.S.
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia and Libya were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to facilitate attacks.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia and Libya were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to facilitate attacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Saudi Arabia and Libya, both considered allies by the United States in its fight against terrorism, were the source of about 60 percent of the foreign fighters who came to Iraq in the past year to serve as suicide bombers or to facilitate other attacks, according to senior American military officials.

articles.headline: Western Union Empire Moves Migrant Cash Home
articles.snippet: Migration is so central to Western Union that forecasts of border movements drive the company’s stock.
articles.abstract: Migration is so central to Western Union that forecasts of border movements drive the company’s stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 — To glimpse how migration is changing the world, consider Western Union, a fixture of American lore that went bankrupt selling telegrams at the dawn of the Internet age but now earns nearly $1 billion a year helping poor migrants across the globe send money home.

articles.headline: Stocks Plummet on ‘Ugly Week’ for Investors
articles.snippet: The Dow fell to its lowest level since April on a day when oil prices moved near the symbolic $100 level.
articles.abstract: The Dow fell to its lowest level since April on a day when oil prices moved near the symbolic $100 level.
articles.lead_paragraph: A late sell-off sent stock markets down sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at its lowest level since April. The plunge came as investors remain frightened and uncertain about a credit crisis that does not show any signs of easing.

articles.headline: For Lawyers, Perks to Fit a Lifestyle
articles.snippet: As law firms pull out the stops to attract top-notch talent, the benefits for lawyers have burgeoned in recent years.
articles.abstract: As law firms pull out the stops to attract top-notch talent, the benefits for lawyers have burgeoned in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even lawyers need a hug. When workdays stretch into worknights and the pressure to meet the quota for billable hours grows, lawyers and staff members at the firm of Perkins Coie can often expect a little bonus.

articles.headline: Fearing Worst, Air Travelers Find Smooth Going
articles.snippet: The confluence of good luck and better planning made for surprisingly smooth holiday travel at many airports across the country.
articles.abstract: The confluence of good luck and better planning made for surprisingly smooth holiday travel at many airports across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: The confluence of good luck and better planning made much of yesterday a surprisingly smooth one for holiday travelers at many airports across the country, passengers, airline executives and their employees said.

articles.headline: Adapting Finance to Islam
articles.snippet: Rising oil wealth is lifting Islamic banking — banking that adheres to the laws of the Koran and its prohibition against charging interest — into the financial mainstream.
articles.abstract: Rising oil wealth is lifting Islamic banking — banking that adheres to the laws of the Koran and its prohibition against charging interest — into the financial mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Rising oil wealth is lifting Islamic banking  banking that adheres to the laws of the Koran and its prohibition against charging interest  into the financial mainstream.

articles.headline: An E-Book Reader That Just May Catch On
articles.snippet: The Kindle is the latest in a long line of e-book readers. Will it succeed where others have failed?
articles.abstract: The Kindle is the latest in a long line of e-book readers. Will it succeed where others have failed?
articles.lead_paragraph: You’ve got to have a lot of nerve to introduce an electronic book reader in 2007.
